title: Bump flask from 1.0.2 to 1.1.2
body:
Bumps [flask](https://github.com/pallets/flask) from 1.0.2 to 1.1.2.
Release notes

Sourced from flask's releases.

1.1.2

1.1.x is the last version to support Python 2.7 and Python 3.5. It also contains deprecation warnings for code that will be removed in 2.0. Please pay attention to deprecation warnings in your project!

This release contains a couple bug fixes.

  • Changelog: https://flask.palletsprojects.com/en/1.1.x/changelog/#version-1-1-2

1.1.1

  • Blog: https://palletsprojects.com/blog/flask-1-1-released
  • Changelog: https://flask.palletsprojects.com/en/1.1.x/changelog/#version-1-1-1

1.1.0

  • Blog: https://palletsprojects.com/blog/flask-1-1-released
  • Changelog: https://flask.palletsprojects.com/en/1.1.x/changelog/#version-1-1-0

1.0.4

  • Changelog: https://flask.palletsprojects.com/en/1.0.x/changelog/#version-1-0-4

1.0.3

  • Changelog: https://flask.palletsprojects.com/en/1.0.x/changelog/#version-1-0-3
Changelog

Sourced from flask's changelog.

Version 1.1.2

Released 2020-04-03

  • Work around an issue when running the flask command with an external debugger on Windows. 3297
  • The static route will not catch all URLs if the Flask static_folder argument ends with a slash. 3452

Version 1.1.1

Released 2019-07-08

  • The flask.json_available flag was added back for compatibility with some extensions. It will raise a deprecation warning when used, and will be removed in version 2.0.0. 3288

Version 1.1.0

Released 2019-07-04

  • Bump minimum Werkzeug version to >= 0.15.
  • Drop support for Python 3.4.
  • Error handlers for InternalServerError or 500 will always be passed an instance of InternalServerError. If they are invoked due to an unhandled exception, that original exception is now available as e.original_exception rather than being passed directly to the handler. The same is true if the handler is for the base HTTPException. This makes error handler behavior more consistent. 3266
    • Flask.finalize_request is called for all unhandled exceptions even if there is no 500 error handler.
  • Flask.logger takes the same name as Flask.name (the value passed as Flask(import_name). This reverts 1.0's behavior of always logging to "flask.app", in order to support multiple apps in the same process. A warning will be shown if old configuration is detected that needs to be moved. 2866
  • flask.RequestContext.copy includes the current session object in the request context copy. This prevents session pointing to an out-of-date object. 2935
  • Using built-in RequestContext, unprintable Unicode characters in Host header will result in a HTTP 400 response and not HTTP 500 as previously. 2994
  • send_file supports ~os.PathLike objects as described in PEP 0519, to support pathlib in Python 3. 3059
  • send_file supports ~io.BytesIO partial content. 2957
  • open_resource accepts the "rt" file mode. This still does the same thing as "r". 3163
  • The MethodView.methods attribute set in a base class is used by subclasses. 3138
  • Flask.jinja_options is a dict instead of an ImmutableDict to allow easier configuration. Changes must still be made before creating the environment. 3190
  • Flask's JSONMixin for the request and response wrappers was moved into Werkzeug. Use Werkzeug's version with Flask-specific support. This bumps the Werkzeug dependency to >= 0.15. 3125
  • The flask command entry point is simplified to take advantage of Werkzeug 0.15's better reloader support. This bumps the Werkzeug dependency to >= 0.15. 3022
  • Support static_url_path that ends with a forward slash. 3134
  • Support empty static_folder without requiring setting an empty static_url_path as well. 3124
  • jsonify supports dataclasses.dataclass objects. 3195
  • Allow customizing the Flask.url_map_class used for routing. 3069
  • The development server port can be set to 0, which tells the OS to pick an available port. 2926
  • The return value from cli.load_dotenv is more consistent with the documentation. It will return False if python-dotenv is not installed, or if the given path isn't a file. 2937
  • Signaling support has a stub for the connect_via method when the Blinker library is not installed. 3208
  • Add an --extra-files option to the flask run CLI command to specify extra files that will trigger the reloader on change. 2897
  • Allow returning a dictionary from a view function. Similar to how returning a string will produce a text/html response, returning a dict will call jsonify to produce a application/json response. 3111
  • Blueprints have a cli Click group like app.cli. CLI commands registered with a blueprint will be available as a group under the flask command. 1357.
  • When using the test client as a context manager (with client:), all preserved request contexts are popped when the block exits, ensuring nested contexts are cleaned up correctly. 3157
  • Show a better error message when the view return type is not supported. 3214
  • flask.testing.make_test_environ_builder() has been deprecated in favour of a new class flask.testing.EnvironBuilder. 3232
  • The flask run command no longer fails if Python is not built with SSL support. Using the --cert option will show an appropriate error message. 3211
  • URL matching now occurs after the request context is pushed, rather than when it's created. This allows custom URL converters to access the app and request contexts, such as to query a database for an id. 3088
... (truncated)
Commits
  • 93dd170 release version 1.1.2
  • 4024a4a update deprecation versions
  • f991a89 Merge pull request #3541 from jeenuv/clarify-static
  • 4548e00 clarify static_folder is relative to root_path
  • c6a619a update CLI docs IDE integration
  • ac9589c Merge pull request #3530 from valleygtc/docs-fix
  • bcf0a95 Merge pull request #3544 from mattc41190/patch-2
  • 1736e01 Grammar and clarity fix
  • 80a597b Merge pull request #3543 from mattc41190/patch-1
  • 8fc723c itty bitty typo
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

[![Dependabot compatibility score](https://api.dependabot.com/badges/compatibility_score?dependency-name=flask&package-manager=pip&previous-version=1.0.2&new-version=1.1.2)](https://dependabot.com/compatibility-score/?dependency-name=flask&package-manager=pip&previous-version=1.0.2&new-version=1.1.2) Dependabot will resolve any conflicts with this PR as long as you don't alter it yourself. title: [Security] Bump requests from 2.19.1 to 2.20.0
body:
Bumps [requests](https://github.com/psf/requests) from 2.19.1 to 2.20.0. **This update includes a security fix.**
Vulnerabilities fixed

Sourced from The GitHub Security Advisory Database.

Moderate severity vulnerability that affects requests The Requests package through 2.19.1 before 2018-09-14 for Python sends an HTTP Authorization header to an http URI upon receiving a same-hostname https-to-http redirect, which makes it easier for remote attackers to discover credentials by sniffing the network.

Affected versions: <= 2.19.1

Changelog

Sourced from requests's changelog.

2.20.0 (2018-10-18)

Bugfixes

  • Content-Type header parsing is now case-insensitive (e.g. charset=utf8 v Charset=utf8).
  • Fixed exception leak where certain redirect urls would raise uncaught urllib3 exceptions.
  • Requests removes Authorization header from requests redirected from https to http on the same hostname. (CVE-2018-18074)
  • should_bypass_proxies now handles URIs without hostnames (e.g. files).

Dependencies

  • Requests now supports urllib3 v1.24.

Deprecations

  • Requests has officially stopped support for Python 2.6.
Commits
  • bd84045 v2.20.0
  • 7fd9267 remove final remnants from 2.6
  • 6ae8a21 Add myself to AUTHORS
  • 89ab030 Use comprehensions whenever possible
  • 2c6a842 Merge pull request #4827 from webmaven/patch-1
  • 30be889 CVE URLs update: www sub-subdomain no longer valid
  • a6cd380 Merge pull request #4765 from requests/encapsulate_urllib3_exc
  • bbdbcc8 wrap url parsing exceptions from urllib3's PoolManager
  • ff0c325 Merge pull request #4805 from jdufresne/https
  • b0ad249 Prefer https:// for URLs throughout project
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

[![Dependabot compatibility score](https://api.dependabot.com/badges/compatibility_score?dependency-name=requests&package-manager=pip&previous-version=2.19.1&new-version=2.20.0)](https://dependabot.com/compatibility-score/?dependency-name=requests&package-manager=pip&previous-version=2.19.1&new-version=2.20.0) Dependabot will resolve any conflicts with this PR as long as you don't alter it yourself. title: [Security] Bump paramiko from 2.4.1 to 2.4.2
body:
Bumps [paramiko](https://github.com/paramiko/paramiko) from 2.4.1 to 2.4.2. **This update includes a security fix.**
Vulnerabilities fixed

Sourced from The GitHub Security Advisory Database.

High severity vulnerability that affects paramiko Paramiko version 2.4.1, 2.3.2, 2.2.3, 2.1.5, 2.0.8, 1.18.5, 1.17.6 contains a Incorrect Access Control vulnerability in SSH server that can result in RCE. This attack appear to be exploitable via network connectivity.

Affected versions: >= 2.4.0, < 2.4.2

title: Bump pyopenssl from 18.0.0 to 19.1.0
body:
Bumps [pyopenssl](https://github.com/pyca/pyopenssl) from 18.0.0 to 19.1.0.
Changelog

Sourced from pyopenssl's changelog.

19.1.0 (2019-11-18)

Backward-incompatible changes:

  • Removed deprecated ContextType, ConnectionType, PKeyType, X509NameType, X509ReqType, X509Type, X509StoreType, CRLType, PKCS7Type, PKCS12Type, and NetscapeSPKIType aliases. Use the classes without the Type suffix instead. #814
  • The minimum cryptography version is now 2.8 due to issues on macOS with a transitive dependency. #875

Deprecations:

  • Deprecated OpenSSL.SSL.Context.set_npn_advertise_callback, OpenSSL.SSL.Context.set_npn_select_callback, and OpenSSL.SSL.Connection.get_next_proto_negotiated. ALPN should be used instead. #820

Changes:

  • Support bytearray in SSL.Connection.send() by using cffi's from_buffer. #852
  • The OpenSSL.SSL.Context.set_alpn_select_callback can return a new NO_OVERLAPPING_PROTOCOLS sentinel value to allow a TLS handshake to complete without an application protocol.

19.0.0 (2019-01-21)

Backward-incompatible changes:

  • X509Store.add_cert no longer raises an error if you add a duplicate cert. #787

Deprecations:

none

Changes:

  • pyOpenSSL now works with OpenSSL 1.1.1. #805
  • pyOpenSSL now handles NUL bytes in X509Name.get_components() #804
Commits
  • da402f4 version bump for 19.1 release (#877)
  • 5d890a0 ALPN: complete handshake without accepting a client's protocols. (#876)
  • 079c963 use _ffi.from_buffer() to support bytearray (#852)
  • 8543286 bump the minimum cryptography version (#875)
  • fc802df Fixes #868 -- test on py38 (#870)
  • 60827f8 Fix for Python 4 (#862)
  • a181373 Expose OP_NO_TLSv1_3 (#861)
  • a539b4c Stop lawyers from emailing Hynek (#856)
  • 963ae03 Mark this test as flaky (#850)
  • 3efa98c Update SSL.py docstring (#849)
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

[![Dependabot compatibility score](https://api.dependabot.com/badges/compatibility_score?dependency-name=pyopenssl&package-manager=pip&previous-version=18.0.0&new-version=19.1.0)](https://dependabot.com/compatibility-score/?dependency-name=pyopenssl&package-manager=pip&previous-version=18.0.0&new-version=19.1.0) Dependabot will resolve any conflicts with this PR as long as you don't alter it yourself. You can also trigger a rebase manually by commenting `@dependabot rebase`. fixed #241

- Python Version: `3.x`
author: aman566
comments_list:
[{'comment_id': 621664265, 'issue_id': 606221235, 'author': '0xInfection', 'body': "This is an interesting addition actually. Good choice @aman566.  :D 

However the checks could be improved well enough by introducing checks like `samesite=strict|lax|None`. Since the introduction of [IETF's Incrementally Better Cookies](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-west-cookie-incrementalism-00), if a site doesn't set the `samesite` attribute to a cookie, the intention of the cookie would be by default set of `samesite=lax`. Also, cookies with `SameSite=None` must also specify `Secure`, meaning they require a secure context. So addition of these checks would enhance the operation of this framework if not causing too false positives. Happy to help (it you want any). :)

> __NOTE:__ Only checking for `samesite` would cause false positives since cookies without a `SameSite` attribute will be treated as `SameSite=Lax`, and this is being considered as a standard since Chrome 80 implemented it and Firefox had it from version 69 itself.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2020, 4, 30, 7, 30, 15, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 621708764, 'issue_id': 606221235, 'author': 'aman566', 'body': "Yeah!!! Thank you @0xInfection I was trying to do that but I don't know the code is breaking. Well I will try once again. Thank you for the feedback :)", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2020, 4, 30, 9, 2, 22, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]
comment_thread:
0xInfection on (2020-04-30 07:30:15 UTC): This is an interesting addition actually. Good choice @aman566.  :D 

However the checks could be improved well enough by introducing checks like `samesite=strict|lax|None`. Since the introduction of [IETF's Incrementally Better Cookies](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-west-cookie-incrementalism-00), if a site doesn't set the `samesite` attribute to a cookie, the intention of the cookie would be by default set of `samesite=lax`. Also, cookies with `SameSite=None` must also specify `Secure`, meaning they require a secure context. So addition of these checks would enhance the operation of this framework if not causing too false positives. Happy to help (it you want any). :)

aman566 (Issue Creator) on (2020-04-30 09:02:22 UTC): Yeah!!! Thank you @0xInfection I was trying to do that but I don't know the code is breaking. Well I will try once again. Thank you for the feedback :)

title: Added all possible conditions to http_cors module
body:
CORS misconfiguration is not only about seeing Access-Control-Allow-Origin: * response header but also Access-Control-Allow-Origin: http://example.foo\r\nAccess-Control-Allow-Credentials: True. If these headers are present that for sure the website is vulnerable to cors.

title: Fixing multiple dependency issues
body:
#### Checklist
- [x] I have followed the [Contributor Guidelines](https://github.com/zdresearch/OWASP-Nettacker/wiki/Developers#contribution-guidelines).
- [x] I have added the relevant documentation.
- [x] My branch is up-to-date with the Upstream master branch.

#### Changes proposed in this pull request
This PR addresses the following issues:
- [x] A missing parenthesis bug (#220).
- [x] Resolves an erring import from `requests` `InsecureRequestWarning`.
- [x] Resolving dependencies between Python2 and Python3 libraries (#222, #223)

#### Additional Information
- This PR address #222 by switching back to pure Python instead of using libraries which cause conflict and problematic backward-compatibility between the two versions.
- `requirements.txt` of this framework marks `requests==2.19.1` as a requirement. However `attack.py` under `core/` uses an outdated version to suppress `InsecureRequestWarning`. This PR addresses the issue by correctly switching the suppress statement to the `urllib3` library.

#### Your development environment
- OS: `Ubuntu`
- OS Version: `18.04`
- Python Version: `v3.6`
author: 0xInfection

aman566 (Issue Creator) on (2020-03-02 17:51:16 UTC): @shaddygarg Sir the custom wordlist is not sufficient. This wordlist will give larger attack surface. Please check and let me know for any issues :)

Ali-Razmjoo on (2020-03-02 20:12:57 UTC): it's always good to have a bigger wordlist, but we don't keep such a thing in the tool since we have this feature.

```
  --method-args METHODS_ARGS
                        enter methods inputs, example: ftp_brute_users=test,ad
                        min&ftp_brute_passwds=read_from_file:/tmp/pass.txt&ftp
                        _brute_port=21
```

you can simply add `--method-args dir_scan_list=read_from_file:/tmp/directories.txt` and load your files. I think it's unnecessary, and that short array is just default values from modules...

aman566 (Issue Creator) on (2020-03-03 01:01:36 UTC): Totally agreeing with you but we can have it as a default wordlist, meaning if someone don't want to have its own that nettacker will search with this one :). Any suggestions?

title: switch to alpine image
body:
#### Checklist
- [x ] I have followed the [Contributor Guidelines](https://github.com/zdresearch/OWASP-Nettacker/wiki/Developers#contribution-guidelines).
- [ ] I have added the relevant documentation. (I don't have access to modify it)
- [x ] My branch is up-to-date with the Upstream master branch.

#### Changes proposed in this pull request
- I have switched to alpine instead of using ubuntu image.
- Added some enhancements like removing the development packages after finishing the installation.
- Used combination of `ENTRYPOINT` and `CMD` so it will be easier to run commands by passing the arguments directly like below instead of typing the whole command:
```
docker run -it --rm owasp-nettacker:latest -i 127.0.0.1 --profile information_gathering
```
- This PR closes #188 

- I have tried to use python 3.7 image which is `python:alpine` but the project dependencies do not support it. for example py3DNS library gives the following:
```
Collecting py3DNS==3.1.1a0 (from -r requirements.txt (line 16))
  Downloading https://files.pythonhosted.org/packages/8e/a3/b8cae77d27ac818390f864583e881ee7d332e2450391ddf1b52dcaaeb521/py3dns-3.1.1a.tar.gz
    Complete output from command python setup.py egg_info:
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
      File "/tmp/pip-install-j64ha9ot/py3DNS/setup.py", line 7, in <module>
        import DNS
      File "/tmp/pip-install-j64ha9ot/py3DNS/DNS/__init__.py", line 27, in <module>
        from .Base import DnsRequest
      File "/tmp/pip-install-j64ha9ot/py3DNS/DNS/Base.py", line 96
        self.async=None
                 ^
    SyntaxError: invalid syntax
```
Should I go with different python version like 3.6 for example ? Let me know so i can test it.

#### Your development environment
- OS: `Linux`
- Python Version: `2.7`
author: mostafahussein

comments_list: [{'comment_id': 813680522, 'issue_id': 414351716, 'author': 'securestep9', 'body': "@codingjustfortest you have good ideas , but this is too much for one PR. I am going to close this and suggest that you submit an individual PR for each module. There were a lot of changes made since your PR and you should review all of them. Please be mindful of the architecture of this project and follow it. Nettacker's strength is that it is 100% Python and must not use/launch any external tools using Popen. It must also be compatible and work fully on Windows/Linux/MacOS and even Raspberry Pi.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2021, 4, 5, 22, 13, 37, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]
comment_thread: securestep9 on (2021-04-05 22:13:37 UTC): @codingjustfortest you have good ideas , but this is too much for one PR. I am going to close this and suggest that you submit an individual PR for each module. There were a lot of changes made since your PR and you should review all of them. Please be mindful of the architecture of this project and follow it. Nettacker's strength is that it is 100% Python and must not use/launch any external tools using Popen. It must also be compatible and work fully on Windows/Linux/MacOS and even Raspberry Pi.

title: socks_proxy decorator (#187)
body:
#### Checklist
- [x] I have followed the [Contributor Guidelines](https://github.com/zdresearch/OWASP-Nettacker/wiki/Developers#contribution-guidelines).
- [x] I have added the relevant documentation.
- [x] My branch is up-to-date with the Upstream master branch.

#### Changes proposed in this pull request
Issue : #187 
This PR adds the feature of using `socks_proxy` template as a python decorator. The steps to use this are as follows : 
1. Importing : `from core.decor import socks_proxy`
2. Put `@socks_proxy` over every function that you wish to decorate. 

As per my best knowledge of the project architecture I have put `decor.py` in the `core` folder. Moreover `decor.py` can be further extended to include multi-threading decorator, for which I wish to open a separate issue. This will save contributors from rewriting long codes every time rather than just focusing on the core concept, rest being handled by decorators.

#### Your development environment
- OS: `Kali Linux`
- OS Version: `2`
- Python Version: `3.6.6`

title: Removed code duplication
body:
#### Checklist
- [x] I have followed the [Contributor Guidelines](https://github.com/zdresearch/OWASP-Nettacker/wiki/Developers#contribution-guidelines).
- [x] I have added the relevant documentation.
- [x] My branch is up-to-date with the Upstream master branch.

#### Changes proposed in this pull request
Issue : #135 

There were a few code duplication in `lib/http_fuzzer/engine.py`, thus violating the DRY principle. This PR deals with those issues.
`timeout_sec` is by default set to `None`. We need not need to create a separate `if-else` regarding this. We can pass `timeout=timeout_sec` provided `timeout=None` is a valid parameter.

We can generate the request statement dynamically by using `eval` function, this will reduce chances of repeating ourselves.

#### Your development environment
- OS: `Kali Linux`
- OS Version: `2`
- Python Version: `3.6.6`

```
.---------------------.------------.
| System              | Value      |

```python
>>> import sys
>>> sys.platform
'linux2'
>>> sys.platform in ['linux','darwin']
False
>>> 'linux' in sys.platform
True
>>>
```

as I mentioned, maybe we need to list of all supported os and then check it like `if os_name() in supported_os():`

regards.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 7, 7, 15, 36, 46, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]

title: Fix for Long Startup Time
body:
#### Checklist
- [x] I have followed the [Contributor Guidelines](https://github.com/zdresearch/OWASP-Nettacker/wiki/Developers#contribution-guidelines).
- [x] I have added the relevant documentation.

#### Changes proposed in this pull request

Fix Issue #163 

#### Your development environment
- OS: `Kali Linux`
- OS Version: `2.0`
- Python Version: `2.7.3`
author: pradeepjairamani
comments_list:
[{'comment_id': 399673839, 'issue_id': 335091222, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': "Hello,

thanks for finding the problem, the VPS hard disk crashed a few days ago and I am working to replace it, but the way disabling this feature is not the best idea but it's solving the problem, anyway we should think about a better solution, what if we get the same situation in feature? should we enable and disable it again? I think it's better if we develop it using the database to check for the update just once in a day, not more, except if the user runs the command to check! looking forward to knowing your idea about this.

updates: please create a new table and name it `options`, then add three columns (`option_name` (string type), `option_value` (string type), `last_modify` (time and date type)) and implement the first option based on sqlalchemy and add `check_for_update` option.

to add this, insert a `check_for_update` in `option_name`, `message_id` (which it using the last version or not from language library based on last checked) in `option_value` and the time of insert as `last_modify`.

startup check for update function must check if the `last_modify` is older than 24 hours ago, it must check for the update and update the `message_id` and `last_modify` otherwise just skip the function. let me know if you have farther questions.

Regards.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 6, 23, 12, 25, 51, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 399941413, 'issue_id': 335091222, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'any thoughts? @pradeepjairamani @shaddygarg', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 6, 25, 12, 54, 24, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 399953712, 'issue_id': 335091222, 'author': 'shaddygarg', 'body': 'I think it is a good idea to do this!!', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 6, 25, 13, 35, 7, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 400571568, 'issue_id': 335091222, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': 'That is a good idea..', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 6, 27, 7, 30, 16, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 400654703, 'issue_id': 335091222, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'so @pradeepjairamani please work on this one.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 6, 27, 12, 30, 42, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 400655274, 'issue_id': 335091222, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': "I tried doing the timeout thing using request but It didn't worked. Let me see if I can find anything else", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 6, 27, 12, 32, 39, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 400695437, 'issue_id': 335091222, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'do you mean this?! working fine for me! 
```python
In [25]: def a(timeout):
    ...:     try:
    ...:         requests.get("http://api.z3r0d4y.com:810/", timeout=timeout)
    ...:     except:
    ...:         pass
    ...:

In [26]: %time a(None)
Wall time: 42.2 s

In [27]: %time a(1)
Wall time: 2 s

In [28]: %time a(3)
Wall time: 6 s
```

anyway after setting the timeout, if you implement the database thing it would be not a problem, 42sec in 24 hours will not count as anything :D! 

Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 6, 27, 14, 35, 42, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]
comment_thread:
Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-06-23 12:25:51 UTC): Hello,

thanks for finding the problem, the VPS hard disk crashed a few days ago and I am working to replace it, but the way disabling this feature is not the best idea but it's solving the problem, anyway we should think about a better solution, what if we get the same situation in feature? should we enable and disable it again? I think it's better if we develop it using the database to check for the update just once in a day, not more, except if the user runs the command to check! looking forward to knowing your idea about this.

updates: please create a new table and name it `options`, then add three columns (`option_name` (string type), `option_value` (string type), `last_modify` (time and date type)) and implement the first option based on sqlalchemy and add `check_for_update` option.

to add this, insert a `check_for_update` in `option_name`, `message_id` (which it using the last version or not from language library based on last checked) in `option_value` and the time of insert as `last_modify`.

startup check for update function must check if the `last_modify` is older than 24 hours ago, it must check for the update and update the `message_id` and `last_modify` otherwise just skip the function. let me know if you have farther questions.

Regards.

Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-06-25 12:54:24 UTC): any thoughts? @pradeepjairamani @shaddygarg

shaddygarg on (2018-06-25 13:35:07 UTC): I think it is a good idea to do this!!

pradeepjairamani (Issue Creator) on (2018-06-27 07:30:16 UTC): That is a good idea..

Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-06-27 12:30:42 UTC): so @pradeepjairamani please work on this one.

pradeepjairamani (Issue Creator) on (2018-06-27 12:32:39 UTC): I tried doing the timeout thing using request but It didn't worked. Let me see if I can find anything else

Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-06-27 14:35:42 UTC): do you mean this?! working fine for me! 
```python
In [25]: def a(timeout):
    ...:     try:
    ...:         requests.get("http://api.z3r0d4y.com:810/", timeout=timeout)
    ...:     except:
    ...:         pass
    ...:

In [26]: %time a(None)
Wall time: 42.2 s

In [27]: %time a(1)
Wall time: 2 s

In [28]: %time a(3)
Wall time: 6 s
```

anyway after setting the timeout, if you implement the database thing it would be not a problem, 42sec in 24 hours will not count as anything :D! 

Regards.

body:

Adding Serviice Scannner module in payload

#### Your development environment
- OS: `Linux Debian`
- OS Version: `Kali 3.0`
- Python Version: `2.7.3`
author: pradeepjairamani
comments_list:
[{'comment_id': 390961472, 'issue_id': 324701828, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Hey Predeep, thanks for your contribution, I've thought about this feature, I come up with an idea and it's worthy to implement. as this will we a service scanner, the first step is to get a signature from the service, so we've to test this in several ways! for instance use socket to send a junk data and see what it returns. I tested the Python `socket` and the `telnetlib`, the `telnetlib` works better, I send a junk and I receive a signature from most of the existing services (`ftp`, `ssh`, `http`, `https`, `smtp`, `pop3` and ...). it seems `telnetlib` is communicating with SSL as well, but there is a few problems that we need to cover them, for example, the size of data we want to send and the data we want to receive, sometimes we've to use `read_some()` and sometimes it's ok to use `read_all()`. after that, we need to list of signatures of common ports/services in a JSON dictionary. for instance: ```json [ {"SERVICE_NAME_1": ["SIGNATURE_1", "SIGNATURE_2"]} {"SERVICE_NAME_2": ["SIGNATURE_1"]} {"SERVICE_NAME_3": ["SIGNATURE_1", "SIGNATURE_2", "SIGNATURE_3"]} (e.g.) {"HTTP": ["Server:", "Content-Length:", "Content-Type:", "HTTP/1.1"]} ] ``` then we can use a `for` loop to detect the possible service. ```python n = 0 for service_name in services_names: FLAG = True for signature in service_names[n][service_name]: if signature not in response: # we are checking if all signatures are available in response not one of them! FLAG = False if FLAG: info("fice service {0}".format(service_name), event={xyz...}) # use messages() lib n += 1 ``` example of using `telnetlib`, `read_some`, `read_all`. ```python In [37]: import telnetlib ...: tn = telnetlib.Telnet("nettacker.z3r0d4y.com", 443, timeout=3) ...: tn.write("\x00"*100) ...: tn.read_some() ...: Out[37]: 'HTTP/1.1 400 Bad Request\r\nServer: nginx\r\nDate: Tue' In [38]: In [38]: import telnetlib ...: tn = telnetlib.Telnet("nettacker.z3r0d4y.com", 443, timeout=3) ...: tn.write("\x00"*100) ...: tn.read_all() ...: Out[38]: 'HTTP/1.1 400 Bad Request\r\nServer: nginx\r\nDate: Tue, 22 May 2018 11:39:09 GMT\r\nContent-Type: text/html\r\nContent-Length: 166\r\nConnection: close\r\n\r\n\r\n400 Bad Request\r\n\r\n

400 Bad Request

\r\n
nginx
\r\n\r\n\r\n' In [39]: In [39]: import telnetlib ...: tn = telnetlib.Telnet("nettacker.z3r0d4y.com", 21, timeout=3) ...: tn.write("\x00"*100) ...: tn.read_all() ...: --> 576 buf = self.sock.recv(50) 577 self.msg("recv %r", buf) 578 self.eof = (not buf) timeout: timed out In [40]: import telnetlib ...: tn = telnetlib.Telnet("nettacker.z3r0d4y.com", 21, timeout=3) ...: tn.write("\x00"*100) ...: tn.read_some() ...: ...: Out[40]: '220 FTP Server ready.\r\n' In [41]: import telnetlib ...: tn = telnetlib.Telnet("nettacker.z3r0d4y.com", 22, timeout=3) ...: tn.write("\x00"*100) ...: tn.read_some() ...: ...: Out[41]: 'SSH-2.0-OpenSSH_5.3\r\n' In [42]: import telnetlib ...: tn = telnetlib.Telnet("nettacker.z3r0d4y.com", 25, timeout=3) ...: tn.write("\x00"*100) ...: tn.read_some() ...: Out[42]: '554 SMTP synchronization error\r\n' In [43]: In [43]: import telnetlib ...: tn = telnetlib.Telnet("nettacker.z3r0d4y.com", 587, timeout=3) ...: tn.write("\x00"*100) ...: tn.read_some() ...: Out[43]: '554 SMTP synchronization error\r\n' In [44]: import telnetlib ...: tn = telnetlib.Telnet("nettacker.z3r0d4y.com", 587, timeout=3) ...: tn.write("\x00"*100) ...: tn.read_some() ...: ``` we also may use multi methods, like connect with socket and `recv_all()` or use `requests` library as well. `telnetlib` doesn't support some SSL versions. ```python In [44]: import telnetlib ...: tn = telnetlib.Telnet("google.com", 443, timeout=3) ...: tn.write("\x00"*100) ...: tn.read_some() ...: ...: Out[44]: '\x15\x03\x01\x02\x02F' In [45]: import telnetlib ...: tn = telnetlib.Telnet("zdresearch.com", 443, timeout=3) ...: tn.write("\x00"*100) ...: tn.read_some() ...: ...: Out[45]: '' In [46]: In [46]: import telnetlib ...: tn = telnetlib.Telnet("z3r0d4y.com", 443, timeout=3) ...: tn.write("\x00"*100) ...: tn.read_some() ...: Out[46]: 'HTTP/1.1 400 Bad Request\r\nServer: cloudflare\r\nDate' ``` or use python socket to recv more data. ```python In [1]: def recv_all(socket): ...: response = "" ...: while 1: ...: try: ...: response += socket.recv(1) ...: except Exception as _: ...: break ...: return response ...: In [2]: import socket In [3]: s = socket.socket(socket.AF_INET, socket.SOCK_STREAM) In [4]: s.settimeout(3) In [5]: s.connect(("nettacker.z3r0d4y.com", 21)) In [6]: s.send("\n\n") # we should consider what we send in here, it's different for some services Out[6]: 2 In [7]: response = recv_all(s) In [8]: response Out[8]: '220 FTP Server ready.\r\n500 Invalid command: try being more creative\r\n500 Invalid command: try being more creative\r\n' In [9]: ``` @pradeepjairamani please review this comment and implement the service scanner, if you have any question feel free to ask and let me know if anyone have any idea! Best Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 5, 22, 11, 47, 51, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 393528527, 'issue_id': 324701828, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Hello, thanks for your contribution, please add the documentation in the wiki (use the readme.md documents). PR merged. Best Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 5, 31, 13, 23, 59, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 393529541, 'issue_id': 324701828, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': 'Hello, Thanks for the help with this and I will update the docs ASAP Best Regards', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 5, 31, 13, 27, 39, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]

title: Implement a http fuzzer for nettacker
body:

- [x] My branch is up-to-date with the Upstream master branch.

#### Changes proposed in this pull request
This pull request implements the http fuzzer library which will be used in all the HTTP fuzzing modules.
#### Work to do:
- ~~Implement all the types of requests (GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE, HEAD)~~
- ~~Add JSON body POST/PUT/PATCH requests type [[1](https://stackoverflow.com/a/26344315)]~~
- ~~Implement multithreading~~
- ~~Implement filters and rules~~
- ~~Real time event system~~
- ~~Write the docstrings for each function~~
- ~~Update the wiki~~

- OS Version: `16.04`
- Python Version: `2.7`

body:
a few upgrades in `port_scan` module
_________________
**OS**: `Linux'

author: VictorSuraj
comments_list:
[{'comment_id': 383486374, 'issue_id': 316692882, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Hey,

Thanks for your contribution, is this necessary to use `global closed_port`? this function defined in the same level of it called.

Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 23, 7, 52, 42, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 383510858, 'issue_id': 316692882, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': 'Hello @VictorSuraj ,

can you please explain me the logic of using global for closed_port variable?

Best Regards', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 23, 9, 21, 41, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 383512932, 'issue_id': 316692882, 'author': 'VictorSuraj', 'body': 'OK I am removing this .   I wanted to use it for fast scanning purpose. But now its no need.
I am going to update engine.py to remove this.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 23, 9, 28, 42, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 383513956, 'issue_id': 316692882, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': 'Hello,

If it is important to use  closed_port globally, you can also use
`closed_port = int()`

Best Regards', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 23, 9, 32, 14, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 383514145, 'issue_id': 316692882, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': "@VictorSuraj, Great,

To be sure, please patch the possible bug.

```python
def check_closed(ip):
    for i in range(1, 10):
        s = sr1(IP(dst=ip) / TCP(dport=i), timeout=2, verbose=0)
        if s != 'SA' and s != None: #if this never happen, function will return None
            return i
```
if in any case, the conditions do not pass the `if`, the function never `return i`. so it's best to add `return 0` in end of function to prevent possible errors.

Regards.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 23, 9, 32, 56, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 383514968, 'issue_id': 316692882, 'author': 'VictorSuraj', 'body': 'I review it, "global closed_port" is used inside function filter_port(ip,port).
I think it well used here. If "global closed_port" remove from function "filter_port( ip,port)" then outputs remains same.
So I think we should remove "global closed_port".', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 23, 9, 35, 59, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 383515727, 'issue_id': 316692882, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': "@VictorSuraj, yes, it's not necessary so you should remove it.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 23, 9, 38, 49, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 383516119, 'issue_id': 316692882, 'author': 'shaddygarg', 'body': 'Hey,
There are four empty lines between two functions : https://github.com/zdresearch/OWASP-Nettacker/pull/112/files#diff-ce3bf9d902408140b4d7678a6395911bR131. You should make them two instead of four.
Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 23, 9, 40, 12, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 383516645, 'issue_id': 316692882, 'author': 'VictorSuraj', 'body': "@Ali-Razmjoo 
No error comes out also in that rare  case if any server's initial ten ports open.
because   here our code check any closed port in initial ten port if any port is closed then it will return 
the port_number.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 23, 9, 42, 2, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 383517924, 'issue_id': 316692882, 'author': 'VictorSuraj', 'body': 'I think we should change as a return 0 in the end if a rare case caused as ten initial port opened in a server 
then it will return None or 0.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 23, 9, 46, 17, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 383518504, 'issue_id': 316692882, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': "@VictorSuraj, so please add `return 0` for the rare cases, also as @shaddygarg mentioned, please use PEP8 style (I can modify your code but it's best to use pycharm or sublime),", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 23, 9, 48, 29, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 383521408, 'issue_id': 316692882, 'author': 'hardlyhuman', 'body': "@VictorSuraj 
I hope with all the feedback you have received, you would be updating this PR. I would also like you to make small changes in your PR. The field `os` in PR Template refers to the operating system that you're using and the version of it in the field `OS Version`.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 23, 9, 59, 3, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 383526810, 'issue_id': 316692882, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Hey @VictorSuraj,

PR Merged, thanks for your contribution (Y), I hope we see more contributions from you. BTW I will glad if you add some comments to the `scapy` part of the code whenever you have time, I am not a pro in scapy library.

Best Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 23, 10, 19, 38, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]
comment_thread:
Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-04-23 07:52:42 UTC): Hey,

Thanks for your contribution, is this necessary to use `global closed_port`? this function defined in the same level of it called.

Regards.

pradeepjairamani on (2018-04-23 09:21:41 UTC): Hello @VictorSuraj ,

can you please explain me the logic of using global for closed_port variable?

Best Regards

VictorSuraj (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-23 09:28:42 UTC): OK I am removing this .   I wanted to use it for fast scanning purpose. But now its no need.
I am going to update engine.py to remove this.

pradeepjairamani on (2018-04-23 09:32:14 UTC): Hello,

If it is important to use  closed_port globally, you can also use
`closed_port = int()`

Best Regards

Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-04-23 09:32:56 UTC): @VictorSuraj, Great,

To be sure, please patch the possible bug.

```python
def check_closed(ip):
    for i in range(1, 10):
        s = sr1(IP(dst=ip) / TCP(dport=i), timeout=2, verbose=0)
        if s != 'SA' and s != None: #if this never happen, function will return None
            return i
```
if in any case, the conditions do not pass the `if`, the function never `return i`. so it's best to add `return 0` in end of function to prevent possible errors.

Regards.

VictorSuraj (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-23 09:35:59 UTC): I review it, "global closed_port" is used inside function filter_port(ip,port).
I think it well used here. If "global closed_port" remove from function "filter_port( ip,port)" then outputs remains same.
So I think we should remove "global closed_port".

Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-04-23 09:38:49 UTC): @VictorSuraj, yes, it's not necessary so you should remove it.

shaddygarg on (2018-04-23 09:40:12 UTC): Hey,
There are four empty lines between two functions : https://github.com/zdresearch/OWASP-Nettacker/pull/112/files#diff-ce3bf9d902408140b4d7678a6395911bR131. You should make them two instead of four.
Regards.

VictorSuraj (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-23 09:42:02 UTC): @Ali-Razmjoo 
No error comes out also in that rare  case if any server's initial ten ports open.
because   here our code check any closed port in initial ten port if any port is closed then it will return 
the port_number.

VictorSuraj (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-23 09:46:17 UTC): I think we should change as a return 0 in the end if a rare case caused as ten initial port opened in a server 
then it will return None or 0.

Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-04-23 09:48:29 UTC): @VictorSuraj, so please add `return 0` for the rare cases, also as @shaddygarg mentioned, please use PEP8 style (I can modify your code but it's best to use pycharm or sublime),

hardlyhuman on (2018-04-23 09:59:03 UTC): @VictorSuraj 
I hope with all the feedback you have received, you would be updating this PR. I would also like you to make small changes in your PR. The field `os` in PR Template refers to the operating system that you're using and the version of it in the field `OS Version`.

Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-04-23 10:19:38 UTC): Hey @VictorSuraj,

PR Merged, thanks for your contribution (Y), I hope we see more contributions from you. BTW I will glad if you add some comments to the `scapy` part of the code whenever you have time, I am not a pro in scapy library.

Best Regards.

[{'comment_id': 382714086, 'issue_id': 315848678, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': "Hey @Ali-Razmjoo,

I am getting this error I think there's some problem with the codacy and travis integration

![screenshot_17](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24669027/38991144-524c4288-43fa-11e8-8ec2-a37e7a5a9766.png)", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 19, 12, 24, 3, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 382768718, 'issue_id': 315848678, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': "Hey,

I recently added the automated code coverage sending to codacy, the environment variable `CODACY_PROJECT_TOKEN` exist already and I've sent some commits, that's weird! let me check to find the problem.

BTW, shouldn't we use the latest version of the modules instead of defining the version? what's your point?

Regards.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 19, 14, 59, 24, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 382845719, 'issue_id': 315848678, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': "Hello,

If there is a previously installed version of any library in python, it doesn't update that library and says requirement already satisfied but when we give it version information it fetches that version even if that module is present.
An example is shown in the image
![screenshot_18](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24669027/39012056-f4a1426e-4430-11e8-89f7-a5e8d1d686d2.png)

On top of that, we can install pyup which will update the requirements.txt with the latest version of modules and create a pull request on its own
[pyup](https://pyup.io/)", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 19, 19, 0, 21, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 382860676, 'issue_id': 315848678, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': "Hey,

Pyup is commercial for organizations, I think if users use `--upgrade` switch it will be installing the latest version, but it's some kind better for virtualenv, so let's merge it!

Regards.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 19, 19, 54, 10, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 382861932, 'issue_id': 315848678, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': 'Hello,

I have installed and tested pyup for the fork of Nettacker and it is free for public repositories, we can implement it.
A screenshot of the same is attached.
![screenshot_19](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24669027/39015215-5183acde-443a-11e8-89c1-71624f62f5c4.png)

Best Regards', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 19, 19, 58, 37, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 382872667, 'issue_id': 315848678, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Hey,

maybe you can monitor it and send the PR, but because it's on your github "user" not organization, you can use pyup for free.

Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 19, 20, 36, 28, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 382881341, 'issue_id': 315848678, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': 'Sure I will monitor and send the PR

Best Regards', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 19, 21, 8, 30, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 382884935, 'issue_id': 315848678, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'thanks.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 19, 21, 22, 25, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]
comment_thread:
pradeepjairamani (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-19 12:24:03 UTC): Hey @Ali-Razmjoo,

I am getting this error I think there's some problem with the codacy and travis integration

![screenshot_17](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24669027/38991144-524c4288-43fa-11e8-8ec2-a37e7a5a9766.png)

Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-04-19 14:59:24 UTC): Hey,

I recently added the automated code coverage sending to codacy, the environment variable `CODACY_PROJECT_TOKEN` exist already and I've sent some commits, that's weird! let me check to find the problem.

BTW, shouldn't we use the latest version of the modules instead of defining the version? what's your point?

Regards.

pradeepjairamani (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-19 19:00:21 UTC): Hello,

If there is a previously installed version of any library in python, it doesn't update that library and says requirement already satisfied but when we give it version information it fetches that version even if that module is present.
An example is shown in the image
![screenshot_18](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24669027/39012056-f4a1426e-4430-11e8-89f7-a5e8d1d686d2.png)

On top of that, we can install pyup which will update the requirements.txt with the latest version of modules and create a pull request on its own
[pyup](https://pyup.io/)

Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-04-19 19:54:10 UTC): Hey,

Pyup is commercial for organizations, I think if users use `--upgrade` switch it will be installing the latest version, but it's some kind better for virtualenv, so let's merge it!

Regards.

pradeepjairamani (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-19 19:58:37 UTC): Hello,

I have installed and tested pyup for the fork of Nettacker and it is free for public repositories, we can implement it.
A screenshot of the same is attached.
![screenshot_19](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24669027/39015215-5183acde-443a-11e8-89c1-71624f62f5c4.png)

Best Regards

Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-04-19 20:36:28 UTC): Hey,

maybe you can monitor it and send the PR, but because it's on your github "user" not organization, you can use pyup for free.

Regards.

pradeepjairamani (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-19 21:08:30 UTC): Sure I will monitor and send the PR

Best Regards

Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-04-19 21:22:25 UTC): thanks.

title: Password List Generator
body:
https://github.com/pradeepjairamani/password_list_generator
Implemented password list generator in lib/payload/password_list_generator.py
Usage:

if you want to output the generated list in a file:


> from lib.payload.password_list_generator import generate
> password_list = generate("word_filename.txt")

if you don't want to output the generated list in a file:

> from lib.payload.password_list_generator import generate
> password_list = generate(None)

2. Implemented Joomla Version Scanner

The joomla version scanner scans for what joomla version the site is using using joomla.xml file 
_________________

**OS**: `Linux`

**OS Version**: `Ubuntu 16.04`

**Python Version**: `2.7.6, 3.4.3`
author: pradeepjairamani
comments_list:
[{'comment_id': 377279186, 'issue_id': 309183144, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Hey,

Thanks for your contribution, a few changes need to be more handy with the framework.

* relocate the generator with `lib/payload/password_generator/engine.py` (use `engine.py` like other modules) and create its own `readme.md` file.
* do not use any `raw_input` or `input`, I should maintain the automating process in the framework for the reason.
* `generate("file.txt")` or `generate(None)` could be optimized. e.g. if user need to create a file it could be `generate(filename="file.txt")` otherwise `generate()` could return an array with passwords. in this case, you may modify the module like this. `def generate(filename=None):`. later we can add other methods to generate the password. e.g
```python
def generate(filename=None, common=None, suffix=False, prefix=False, username=None):
# generate common passwords
# generate with the suffix
# generate with the prefix
# generate depend on the username (e.g. username="Ali", output: ["Ali1", "Ali123", "Ali123!", "Ali!@#", "Ali2018"])
```
* if you need to `print` something, please use `core.alert` 
* use `core.log.__log_into_file(filename, mode, data, language, final=True)` for writing files (notice: use `final=True`)
* apply PEP8 fix the lib
* do not forget to add `__init__.py` to the lib folder.
* add code based docuemntation.
* add the document into your readme (like you did) I will add them to wiki

#1 I should probably write these roles in the documents too.

Best Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 3, 29, 15, 46, 31, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 377300645, 'issue_id': 309183144, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': 'Ok, I will make the changes and
Please give me a little tip for taking input without input or raw_input
secondly there is no need for the username as in the data is already being generated from user specified details like name, last name, email, etc.

Best Regards
Pradeep Jairamani', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 3, 29, 16, 54, 21, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 377316770, 'issue_id': 309183144, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Hi,

you may use default values and create an input method for changing the defaults.

my bad, I think using the default (like I said) would solve this.

let me know if you have any more questions.

```python
def generate(filename=None, common=None, suffix=False, prefix=False, username=None):
# generate common passwords
# generate with the suffix
# generate with the prefix
# generate depend on the username (e.g. username="Ali", output: ["Ali1", "Ali123", "Ali123!", "Ali!@#", "Ali2018"])
```
* if you need to `print` something, please use `core.alert` 
* use `core.log.__log_into_file(filename, mode, data, language, final=True)` for writing files (notice: use `final=True`)
* apply PEP8 fix the lib
* do not forget to add `__init__.py` to the lib folder.

I've checked your PR, the second `break` in the code was for the `for` loop but it seems I implemented it wrong! two `break`s are not working after each other, this PR also need to be fixed.

I've found a solution on [StackOverFlow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/653509/breaking-out-of-nested-loops) and [here](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3136/). please implement a new solution to break the `for` loop in the `while` loop. let me know if you want any help.

Best Regards.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 2, 14, 18, 29, 45, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 365725923, 'issue_id': 297038309, 'author': 'shaddygarg', 'body': "Hi, 
Thanks for the quick review. I saw the solution on StackOverFlow. It is fascinating to know but it doesn't consider the case when internal break is caused by the else block. Therefore, I implemented it using a variable `keyboard_interrupt_flag` and an `if-else` block. Let me know any further improvements!
Thanks and regards.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 2, 14, 19, 55, 3, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 366421933, 'issue_id': 297038309, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Hello @shaddygarg,

Sorry for the delay in responding and thank you for your contribution. I committed a simple[[1]](https://github.com/viraintel/OWASP-Nettacker/commit/578274699dc64b15c0997eab37c11d8e30b74f56) change.

I hope we see more contributions from you in future.

Best Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 2, 17, 6, 47, 34, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]
comment_thread:
Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-02-14 17:55:41 UTC): Hello,


thank you for your contribution, I'll review and get back to you soon.

Best regards.

Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-02-14 18:29:45 UTC): Hello,

I've checked your PR, the second `break` in the code was for the `for` loop but it seems I implemented it wrong! two `break`s are not working after each other, this PR also need to be fixed.

I've found a solution on [StackOverFlow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/653509/breaking-out-of-nested-loops) and [here](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-3136/). please implement a new solution to break the `for` loop in the `while` loop. let me know if you want any help.

Best Regards.

shaddygarg (Issue Creator) on (2018-02-14 19:55:03 UTC): Hi, 
Thanks for the quick review. I saw the solution on StackOverFlow. It is fascinating to know but it doesn't consider the case when internal break is caused by the else block. Therefore, I implemented it using a variable `keyboard_interrupt_flag` and an `if-else` block. Let me know any further improvements!
Thanks and regards.

Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-02-17 06:47:34 UTC): Hello @shaddygarg,

Sorry for the delay in responding and thank you for your contribution. I committed a simple[[1]](https://github.com/viraintel/OWASP-Nettacker/commit/578274699dc64b15c0997eab37c11d8e30b74f56) change.

I hope we see more contributions from you in future.

Best Regards.

title: windows 10 bug fixed
body:
__log_into_file function is creating an error
	

It's due to the default behaviour of open in Python 3. By default, Python 3 will open files in Text mode, which means that it also has to apply a text decoding, such as utf-8 or ASCII, for every character it reads.

Python will use your locale to determine the most suitable encoding. On OS X and Linux, this is usually UTF-8. On Windows, it'll use an 8-bit character set, such windows-1252, to match the behaviour of Notepad.

so i added encoding with open. this fixed the error.

Describe your changes or your new module and let us know which OS and Python version you tested on.
_________________
**OS**: `windows`

**OS Version**: `windows 10`

**Python Version**: `3.6`

title: added filelock support to avoid collision while writing logs
body:
Regarding #22 

Created ` __log_into_file(filename, mode, data)` in [core/log.py](https://github.com/avhvr/OWASP-Nettacker/blob/master/core/log.py#L88) 
used [filelock](https://filelock.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) module (works on windows too)

changed blocks of code in following files: 

- lib/brute/smtp/engine.py
- lib/brute/ssh/engine.py
- lib/brute/ftp/engine.py
- lib/vuln/heartbleed/engine.py
- lib/scan/dir/engine.py
- lib/scan/viewdns_reverse_ip_lookup/engine.py
- lib/scan/tcp_connect_port/engine.py
- lib/scan/subdomain/engine.py

Feedback is appreciated
_________________
**OS**: `KDE neon LTS`

**OS Version**: `5.8`

**Python Version**: `3.5.2`
author: avhvr-zz

I believe the new function is working wrong. I've two questions regarding this.
* why you are using `write_blocks` array and appending the file name in it without using it anywhere else?
* should `flock = lockfile.FileLock(filename)` be inside the `if` ? i've tested it outside the if, framework is working fine!
```
def __log_into_file(filename, mode, data):

    if filename not in write_blocks:
        write_blocks.append(filename)
        flock = lockfile.FileLock(filename)

    flock.acquire()
    with open(filename, mode) as save:
        save.write(data + '\n')
    flock.release()
```
